Using case studies from the Balkans, Cyprus, and other European borderlands as a point of departure, the gathering will bring together an array of scholars for an informal series of conversations that will seek to understand how our present-day notions of what constitute "war-crimes" both shape, and are shaped by, the contemporary moment. Articles Mary Nolan, "Germans as Victims During the Second World War: Air Wars, Memory Wars" Mark Mazower, "An International Civilization? 125th Anniversary, GSAS | NYU                                                 Navigation       Graduate School of Arts and Science                 About Arts and Science | Departments and Programs | The Faculty       About GSAS | Programs | Admissions | Students | Alumni | Give to GSAS               Home > About GSAS > History > 125th Anniversary           125th Anniversary                                                                                                                                                        Our Roots    The earned graduate degree came of age in the United States in the 1860s. Until that time, advanced degrees were essentially honorary acknowledgements of devotion to a discipline. In 1866, the University of the City of New York, known since 1888 as New York University, became one of the first institutions in the country to award a doctoral degree for successful completion of academic work. Read more  Graduate Education at a Research University At its founding, the Graduate Division offered courses in just thirteen subjects, with most students studying philosophy, economics, languages, literature or pedagogy. This limited curriculum was further narrowed by an early decision to move the field of pedagogy into a separate school, consistent with the prevailing vision for graduate education to be distinct from professional fields.
